title: Episode 169 – Jeff Poppen, Author, “Barefoot Biodynamics”
subtitle: Jeff Poppen, Author,Barefoot Biodynamics: How Cows, Compost, and Community Help Us Understand Rudolf Steiner’s Agriculture Course
description: Discussing his decades-long experiences as a Biodynamic farmer in Tennessee, Jeff Poppen distills the key principles and practices of this advanced form of organic stewardship, fertility-building, and nutrient dense food production first articulated by Rudolf Steiner one hundred years ago in the “Agriculture Lectures.” With three separate doctorate degrees (mathematics, biology, and chemistry), Rudolf Steiner promulgated an incisive – if at times esoteric – way of understanding the more subtle (and vital) dynamics at work in the exceedingly complex ecosystems of soil, plants, and atmosphere. Steiner’s recommended methodologies are grounded in robust knowledge of living systems that transcends the basic – and all too limited – mechanistic attitudes prevalent in conventional modern agriculture which often result in degraded soils, depleted nutrition, water pollution, and constrained long term economic viability for farmers beholden to a treadmill of expensive chemical and mechanical inputs. In his book,Barefoot Biodynamics, Poppen summarizes Steiner’s essential recommendations into an easy-to-understand framework that reflects decades of experience and exploration, and that ultimately helps us to comprehend the essential connection between real, robust nutrition and our mental, spiritual, and willful wellbeing.

about_sections.about_jeff_poppen: Jeff Poppen, a Midwestern farm boy, helped develop an organic farm and Tennessee homestead in the mid-1970s, and ten years later began applying biodynamic methods and making the preparations to do so. His livelihood comes primarily from vegetables and cattle grown on the 270-acre Long Hungry Creek Farm, where cows, compost, and community keep the land vibrant and productive. Jeff advocates for a more peaceful agriculture by mentoring young farmers and gardeners, along with a bit of lecturing, consulting, hosting events, and facilitating a few new farm enterprises. His style of old-time farming comes from paying close attention to what elder farmers thought, felt, and did, and by studying how farms were managed before agricultural chemicals were first manufactured on a large scale over one hundred years ago. He is the author ofBarefoot Biodynamics: How Cows, Compost, and Community Help Us Understand Rudolf Steiner’s Agriculture Course, and like his animals, he gets his food from the farm.
about_sections.about_chelsea_green_publishing: Founded in 1984, Chelsea Green Publishing is recognized as a leading publisher of books on the politics and practice of sustainable living, publishing authors who bring in-depth, practical knowledge to life, and give readers hands-on information related to organic farming and gardening, permaculture, ecology, the environment, simple living, food, sustainable business and economics, green building, and more. segments.text: Welcome to the Why on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today
we're visiting with Jeff Hoppin, the author of Barefoot Bio Dynamics. Hey Jeff, how you doing?
Good. I'm really excited to visit with you today and talk about your book. It's one of my new favorites in the archives of the Bio-Dynamic literature.
Okay, I'm glad you enjoyed it.
Yeah.
Jeff Poppin, a Midwestern farm boy, helped develop an organic farm and Tennessee homestead in the mid 1970s.
And 10 years later began applying bio-Dynamic methods and making the preparations to do so. His livelihood comes primarily from vegetables and cattle grown on the 270 acre long hungry creek farm,

where cows, compost and community keep the land vibrant and productive. Jeff advocates for a more peaceful agriculture by mentoring young farmers and gardeners along with a bit of lecturing, consulting, hosting events, and facilitating a few new farm enterprises.

His style of old time farming comes from paying close attention to what elder farmers thought felt and did. And by studying how farms were managed before agricultural chemicals were first manufactured on a large scale over 100 years ago.
Like his animals, he gets his food from the farm.
And Jeff, this phrasing, how cows, compost and community help us understand Rudolph's, Rudolph's, China's, agriculture course, which is of course the subtitle of your book is beautiful.
It's cows, compost and community. Can you help kind of frame this up for us and why cows, compost and community are so important?
Well, we all like alliteration and that's nice.
I think that one of the differences in bio-Dynamic farms is that they generally have both cows and crops mixed.
And then I've always just been a huge fan of compost. It's just my favorite thing I think.
So it really makes the farm a lovely place. So I'm going to stress that and community of course because farm has lots to do and lots to enjoy and just way more than you can do yourself.
Well, your book has such an effective way of walking the reader through what it seems to me are many of the core and foundational principles and axioms of bio-Dynamic farming.
And frankly, like so many of Rudolph Steiner's lectures and writings, it's not the easiest material to approach.
And the way in which you've unpacked and interpreted Steiner's work is really wonderful.
And I'm holding the book up for our audience who are with us checking out the video.
This is the book. It's beautiful, published by Chelsea Green Publishing. It's what a great resource.
I'm so glad you enjoyed it. It's the result of a long study of what he was trying to say in those lectures given in 1924.
And I had helped in writing the book and that I'm not an academic and more of like a practical farmer.
And so when I started writing was for a local people that had about, you know, maybe a grade school education, a little bit of high school.
And that sort of was what I wrote for the local newspaper.
And so I really try to close my writing and something that is easy to understand so that people can understand it.
Right. And not use words that people don't know what I kind of think.
What?
I use a lot of words that I didn't want to use.
I mean to us.
Yeah. Well, I so appreciate too how you sprinkle so much humor throughout the book.
I'm chocolate every other page.
Well, I think I stressed the standards due to the humor was essential for any kind of enlightenment and agriculture is true and need of some enlightenment.
Yeah, in every sense of the word, huh?
Yeah.

You know, one of the things you're doing in the book and I want to encourage everybody who is gardening and farming and wanting to learn more about biodynamics and the unique tools that biodynamics provides to us.

One of the things you're doing in your book that I really appreciate is you're presenting and discussing the complex interplay and interaction between various elements and chemical compositions and the complexity of the life itself in the floor of the fauna, the fungi.

And you explain it in a way that at least to me is like, OK, this is pretty straightforward to understand even though it's dealing with some pretty one would say maybe arcane or less common ways of thinking about fertility and thinking about the ecosystem of the farm, the ecosystem of the garden.

And yeah, it's amazing, right? And obviously, Steiner in his work is talking about a lot of aspects of our role as stewards that is not commonplace in conventional, conventional, modern farming, right?
It's what you're doing and what you're writing about is very different from the sort of status quo business as usual of chemical agriculture, isn't it?
Yeah, it is a different mindset, I guess.

Something I learned a long time ago is that decisions made for a farm organism need to be made from observation and interaction with the farm organism and not from any kind of outside economic compelling reasons.
And so even though we made suffer economically in the long run, it's going to be better because you're doing the best things for the farm.
And this may be working on pasture management and the same that we'll have cattle sales 10 years later or something.
And you know, and you just are all the time doing this stuff for a long term because you live there, you want to live there.
That's really the only thing that you get out of the old and you get to live there.
That's paper, well.
And that's what you just want to do.
I hope that answered the question.

Yeah, I think so. And you know, one of the things that jumped out at me in the book is, you say, a big part of the profit, quote unquote, profit that comes from your approach to farming is the culture and the community that you get to experience and the quality of life that goes along with that.
Yeah, absolutely.
So it's a wonderful.
I mean, I don't have any other experience per se.
So it's hard to compare like it does seem like I have a lot of neighborliness and stuff around here.
Yeah, but there's also the broader community of being part of the 50 years of organic farming movement and having taken that to be.
But I thought was way forward and what Mike calling was to figure that out, which I'm all the way from doing.
I just think that's a little bit more sustainably.
Wow, a big tour.
You know, growing food and having enough to sell a little bit.
Quite, quite.
Very interesting.
Yeah.
Beautiful.
Well, I want to dive into some of the detail around what you call nitrogen and her sisters, different elements and compounds at a very important functions in the farm ecosystem.
